study_goal: To assess the effects of LP IS-10506 supplementation on immune markers and symptoms in adults with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The probiotic group showed significantly lower SCORAD scores, IL-4, and IL-17 levels, and higher IFN-γ and Foxp3+ levels compared to placebo, but IgE levels remained unchanged. The probiotic was effective in alleviating AD symptoms due to immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: Adults with mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: To determine whether protein-supplemented human milk improves growth, body composition, cardio-metabolic, and neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm infants compared to unsupplemented human milk.
results_summary: Protein supplementation of human milk increased short-term growth in weight, length, and head circumference but may lead to longer hospital stays. The effects on feeding intolerance, necrotizing enterocolitis, and neurodevelopmental outcomes remain uncertain due to very low-quality evidence.
population_specificity: Hospitalized preterm infants fed human milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carbohydrate-supplemented human milk improves growth, body composition, and cardio-metabolic and neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm infants without significant adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that preterm infants receiving carbohydrate-supplemented human milk had greater weight gain at 30 days and shorter hospital stays compared to the unsupplemented group, but the evidence was of very low quality, and no clear differences were observed in feeding intolerance or necrotising enterocolitis.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in a hospital setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in dietary iodine intake, potassium iodide supplementation, and smoking habits, and their impact on urinary iodine concentration (UIC) during pregnancy.
results_summary: The percentage of women with a desirable UIC (≥150 μg/L) increased from the first to the second trimester (57.3% to 68.9%) and remained stable in the third (68%).
population_specificity: Pregnant women monitored in the public health system in Central and North Metropolitan areas of Catalonia, Spain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide a comprehensive overview of the traditional heritage, pharmacological benefits, chemical fingerprint, metabolism, and bioavailability of S. marianum (Milk thistle) extracts and metabolites.
results_summary: S. marianum has been extensively studied for its hepatoprotective, antidiabetic, cardiovascular, anticancer, and antimicrobial activities, but clinical evidence of its real efficiency remains limited. Few studies have explored its metabolism, pharmacokinetics, and bioavailability.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human use implied).

study_goal: To determine whether fat supplementation of human milk improves growth, body composition, cardio-metabolic, and neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm infants without significant adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found no clear evidence that fat supplementation improved short-term growth or increased feeding intolerance in preterm infants, but the evidence was of very low quality due to small sample size and lack of long-term outcome data.
population_specificity: Preterm infants fed human milk in hospital.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the acute effects of maternal lipid-based nutrient supplementation (LNS) on milk B-vitamin concentrations and infant intake.
results_summary: Maternal supplementation with LNS (either as a single bolus or divided doses) significantly increased milk and infant intakes of riboflavin, thiamin, and pyridoxal, while only the bolus dose increased cobalamin. Niacin levels remained unaffected.
population_specificity: 26 mother-infant dyads (4-6 months postpartum) in Quetzaltenango, Guatemala.
effective_dosage: Bolus: 30-g single dose; Divided: 3 × 10-g doses over 8 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether milk fat globule membrane (MFGM) supplementation modulates motor unit adaptation following resistance training in older adults.
results_summary: MFGM supplementation maintained motor unit firing rates during resistance training, unlike the placebo group, which showed significant decreases. No significant differences were observed in muscle thickness or maximal strength between the groups.
population_specificity: Older males and females (n=25, with 12 in each group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a fortified milk supplement combined with exercise on vitamin B-12, 25(OH)D levels, bone turnover markers, and parathyroid hormone concentrations in middle-aged and older Chinese adults.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased serum vitamin B-12 and 25(OH)D concentrations and improved the balance of bone turnover markers, suggesting reduced bone remodeling, but did not significantly affect parathyroid hormone levels.
population_specificity: Chinese middle-aged and older adults (mean age 61 ± 6 years, 85 women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term ingestion of low-dose milk protein supplementation increases muscle mass and strength in older adults during low-to-moderate intensity exercise training compared to isocaloric carbohydrate.
results_summary: The study found that milk protein supplementation significantly increased lean body mass and reduced fat mass and plasma uric acid levels in older adults, but did not improve physical performance compared to the placebo group. Both groups showed improvements in physical performance tests, with no significant differences between them.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 60-84 years.
effective_dosage: 10 g of milk protein per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dose of a 4:1 mix of 2'-O-fucosyllactose and Lacto-N-neotetraose (2'FL/LNnT) that increases fecal bifidobacteria abundance without worsening gastrointestinal symptoms in IBS patients.
results_summary: The 10 g dose of 2'FL/LNnT increased fecal bifidobacteria abundance at week 4 without aggravating gastrointestinal symptoms, and responders showed distinct fecal microbiota modulation. No symptom deterioration was observed in any group.
population_specificity: Patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) diagnosed according to Rome IV criteria.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention followed by a 4-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of probiotics in fermented milk as a potential dietary treatment for hypertension by analyzing its effects on blood pressure.
results_summary: Probiotic consumption significantly reduced systolic blood pressure by -3.05 mmHg and diastolic blood pressure by -1.51 mmHg, with notable effects in hypertension and type 2 diabetes patients, though benefits were short-term (8-10 weeks).
population_specificity: Hypertension and type 2 diabetes patients (2037 participants across 23 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of fortifying breast milk for preterm infants to meet their nutritional needs and improve short-term outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that fortification of breast milk in preterm infants is supported by strong evidence for better short-term outcomes, with individualized strategies potentially offering superior results compared to standard fortification. Human milk-derived fortification shows promise, but its benefits in exclusively human milk-fed preterm infants remain unclear.
population_specificity: Preterm and term infants, with a focus on preterm infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review factors influencing early-life gut microbiome colonization, including infant feeding practices.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the association between early-life gut microbiome alterations and chronic health conditions, emphasizing the role of infant feeding and supplementation strategies.
population_specificity: Neonates and infants, with a focus on maternal and infant factors affecting gut colonization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of milk supplementation on circulating IGF-1 and its correlation with growth and cognition in children.
results_summary: Milk supplementation (8.8 g milk protein/day) significantly increased IGF-1 levels, which was associated with improvements in cognitive function and growth metrics like height, weight, and fat-free mass. Lower doses or mixed protein supplements did not show significant effects.
population_specificity: 6-9-year-old children from rural Ghana.
effective_dosage: 8.8 g milk protein/day (Milk8), 4.4 g milk protein/day (Milk4), or 4.4 g milk + 4.4 g rice protein/day (Milk/rice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding two human milk oligosaccharides (2'-fucosyllactose and lacto-N-) to infant formula influences early-life intestinal microbiota development compared to standard formula.
results_summary: The study found that infant formula supplemented with two HMOs may shape the development of the early-life intestinal microbiota, suggesting potential health benefits for infants. The abstract implies a positive effect but does not provide detailed outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy term infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of oat-based RUTF (without milk powder) versus standard RUTF (containing milk powder) in treating severe acute malnutrition in children.
results_summary: Oat-RUTF showed superior outcomes compared to s-RUTF, with higher graduation rates (56% vs. 45%), lower adverse outcomes (12% vs. 18%), and faster recovery times. Weight gain rates were also significantly higher in the oat-RUTF group.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-59 months with severe acute malnutrition in rural Sierra Leone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oral supplementation with early-life microbiota (probiotics) on the gut microbiota of preterm infants.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the supplementation.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (101 supplemented infants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutrient content of human milk and its adequacy for infant growth, as well as the effects of maternal diet and supplementation on milk micronutrient concentrations.
results_summary: The study found that existing AI recommendations for infants are based on poor data, and some nutrients in milk may not be adequate even in well-nourished mothers. Maternal diet quality significantly affects milk micronutrient concentrations, and new methods are being used to analyze these variations.
population_specificity: Healthy, well-nourished, unsupplemented mother-infant dyads in four countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of different doses of a milk-based vitamin D supplement on cardiometabolic risk markers in young healthy children.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in cardiometabolic markers (lipids, blood pressure, CRP) between groups receiving different vitamin D doses or placebo. Baseline serum 25(OH)D was negatively associated with blood pressure, but supplementation did not affect outcomes.
population_specificity: Healthy 5- to 7-year-old Swedish children with fair and dark skin.
effective_dosage: 10 µg or 25 µg vitamin D3 daily (placebo: 2 µg at 55°N only).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of low milk consumption in contributing to vitamin B12 deficiency and its long-term health effects, particularly in adolescents and their offspring.
results_summary: The study found that low milk consumption was one of several factors contributing to vitamin B12 deficiency, which was associated with fetal growth restriction and increased diabetes risk factors in offspring. A pilot trial showed improved metabolic parameters with small-dose B12 supplementation, leading to a larger intervention trial in adolescents.
population_specificity: Indian adolescents and their offspring, with a focus on those with subclinical B12 deficiency due to vegetarianism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and effects of a probiotic supplement on immune system development in formula-fed infants.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the probiotic supplement's effects on immune system development in formula-fed infants.
population_specificity: Formula-fed infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how milk ingredients could enhance the attachment of health-promoting bacteria to the gut mucosal surface.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that milk components may increase commensal bacterial adherence in the gut, potentially benefiting individuals with lower levels of health-promoting bacteria like bifidobacteria. However, no specific experimental results or clinical outcomes are detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals at different life stages or those with diseases linked to reduced health-promoting bacteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of protein supplementation in very low birth weight infants on neurological growth by the third year of birth.
results_summary: Protein supplementation showed no significant effect on head circumference growth but improved neurological development in communication, gross motor (ASQ tool), and auditory, verbal language, cognitive, social connection, and motor skills (NEWSHA tool). No significant differences were found in fine motor, problem-solving, or personal-social relationships.
population_specificity: Very low birth weight infants (under 1200 grams at birth).
effective_dosage: Protein was added to maternal milk once intake reached 100 cc/kg/day, with fortifier (FMS-Aptamil-DANON) until weight reached 1500 grams.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the efficacy of Bifidobacteria supplementation on abdominal pain in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The study found conflicting results from RCTs regarding the efficacy of Bifidobacteria in improving abdominal pain in IBS patients, with a total of 8 RCTs involving 1045 patients analyzed.
population_specificity: Patients with Rome-diagnosed irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
effective_dosage: The dose of total Bifidobacteria ranged from 10 (units not specified).

study_goal: To evaluate the effect of maternal dietary supplementation of complex milk lipids (CML) from the milk fat globule membrane (MFGM) during pregnancy on fetal growth, particularly head circumference.
results_summary: Supplementation with CML-enriched milk had no effects on fetal growth in any biometric dimensions. The absence of adverse growth outcomes suggests maternal MFGM supplementation is safe.
population_specificity: 1500 pregnant women from Chongqing Municipality, China, recruited between 11 and 14 weeks of pregnancy.
effective_dosage: Control (4 mg GA/day) vs. CML-enriched (8 mg GA/day) vs. no supplementation.
study_duration: From the end of the first trimester until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) could be recovered in the faeces of healthy young Australian adults after consuming a fermented milk drink.
results_summary: The study found that LcS was recoverable in all participants' faeces during supplementation (days 7 and 14) but was detectable in only one sample 14 days after cessation. The supplement was well tolerated.
population_specificity: 25 healthy young Australian adults (14 male, 11 female; mean age 29.3±6.6 years; mean BMI 25.3±2.7 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 65 ml of fermented milk containing 6.5×10⁹ LcS live cells daily.
study_duration: 14 days of supplementation, with follow-up until day 28.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective properties of milk sphingomyelin (SM) against dysfunctional lipid metabolism, gut dysbiosis, and inflammation.
results_summary: Dietary milk SM reduced intestinal absorption of cholesterol, triglycerides, and fatty acids in cell and rodent studies, with some hypolipidemic effects observed in human trials. Milk SM also improved gut microbiota and barrier function in preclinical studies, though human effects were less pronounced.
population_specificity: Rodents and humans (limited human trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily supplementation with cow milk, egg, and multiple micronutrients improves linear growth in undernourished Bangladeshi children aged 12-18 months.
results_summary: The study found that daily supplementation with milk, egg, and micronutrients significantly improved linear growth (LAZ increase of +0.23) compared to the control group, with no reported allergic reactions or adverse events related to milk consumption. The effect was more pronounced in stunted children (LAZ <2).
population_specificity: Undernourished Bangladeshi children aged 12-18 months with length-for-age z score (LAZ) <1.
effective_dosage: 150 mL of cow milk daily for 90 feeding days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare growth and cost outcomes of infants ≤1250 g birth weight fed with an exclusive human milk diet, with and without human milk cream, without using a human milk analyzer.
results_summary: The study found no difference in weight or head circumference growth between the two groups, but length velocity was greater in the group without cream. The cream-supplemented group used less fortifier and saved an average of $2318 per patient on human milk products.
population_specificity: Premature infants ≤1250 g birth weight.
effective_dosage: Not specified (cream supplement was added if weight gain was <15 g/kg/d).
study_duration: From birth to 34 weeks postmenstrual age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential benefits of fortifying milk with vitamin D to address low serum 25(OH)D concentrations and associated diseases in Mongolia.
results_summary: The study found that Mongolians have low serum 25(OH)D levels, linked to various diseases, and suggested fortifying milk with vitamin D as a potential solution.
population_specificity: Mongolians with low serum 25(OH)D concentrations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of maternal iodine supplementation (via capsules or iodized salt) on maternal and infant thyroid function and infant visual information processing.
results_summary: Iodine supplementation significantly reduced maternal TSH and goiter prevalence. Higher breast milk iodine concentration (BMIC) and other factors (e.g., maternal education, household food security) predicted better infant novelty quotient scores in visual information processing.
population_specificity: Mother-infant dyads (n = 106) within the first 10 days postpartum.
effective_dosage: 225 μg iodine daily (capsule) or iodized salt weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of nutrient-enriched donor milk compared with preterm formula on growth, body composition, and blood pressure in children born preterm and with very-low-birth-weight (VLBW).
results_summary: Nutrient-enriched donor milk and preterm formula resulted in comparable long-term growth and body composition in VLBW children. In-hospital mother's milk intake was positively associated with height z score at 5.5 years.
population_specificity: Children born preterm with very-low-birth-weight (<1500 g).
effective_dosage: ≥120 mL·kg-1·d-1 of nutrient-enriched donor milk or preterm formula.
study_duration: Median 67.5 days (IQR 52.0-91.0 days) or until hospital discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 24-week multidomain lifestyle intervention, including a nutritional milk supplement and exercise, improved physical and cognitive function, self-rated health, and health-related quality of life in older Chinese adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in gait speed, muscle strength, muscle power, cardiovascular fitness, or cognitive function, but self-rated health and moderate physical activity levels improved in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Community-living Chinese adults aged 50 years and older (mean age 61 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore lactose digestion, malabsorption, and intolerance, including genetic mechanisms, diagnostic methods, and treatment options.
results_summary: The study found that lactose intolerance (LI) results from lactose malabsorption (LM) and can cause abdominal symptoms, with risk factors including lactose dose, lactase expression, and intestinal microbiome. Treatment options like low-lactose diets and lactase supplementation show modest clinical outcomes.
population_specificity: Individuals with lactose malabsorption, lactose intolerance, and conditions like IBS or visceral hypersensitivity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enteral supplementation with prebiotics reduces the incidence of hyperbilirubinaemia in term and preterm infants compared to milk supplementation with placebo or no supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that prebiotic supplementation may reduce the risk of hyperbilirubinaemia and phototherapy need, but results were inconsistent. It also showed a significant reduction in hospital stay length and increased stool frequency, but no significant difference in bilirubin levels, phototherapy duration, or mortality.
population_specificity: Term and preterm neonates

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of a protein-rich nutritional supplement containing donkey milk on intestinal mucosal barrier function and gastrointestinal outcomes in severe pneumonia patients.
results_summary: The study found that the protein-rich supplement (including donkey milk) reduced blood DAO, D-LC, and bacterial endotoxin levels, improved intestinal mucosal barrier function, and reduced gastrointestinal motility disorder incidence in severe pneumonia patients.
population_specificity: 108 severe pneumonia patients from The First People's Hospital of Fuyang.
effective_dosage: 20g/d of a compound containing donkey milk, Badanmu, and Chamagu.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe infant and toddler nutrition patterns, including milk consumption, and assess adherence to dietary guidelines using NHANES data.
results_summary: The study provides an update on NHANES nutrition monitoring for children under 2 years, including milk-based eating patterns, but does not specifically report on milk's effects. It highlights trends in dietary intakes and adherence to recommendations like those from the AAP.
population_specificity: US children aged birth to 24 months (B-24).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the value and risks of using donor human milk for infants, considering donor selection, processing methods, and ethical standards.
results_summary: The study highlights the need for careful risk assessment and ethical considerations in donor human milk use, emphasizing that benefits must outweigh known hazards. It also notes the importance of avoiding displacement of maternal lactation when supplementing with donor milk.
population_specificity: Infants receiving donor human milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of nutrition, including breast milk and fatty acid supplementation, on postnatal brain development in premature and term infants.
results_summary: Fat and energy intake were associated with improved brain volume and development in premature infants. Breast milk and long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acid supplementation showed benefits in term infants, but their impact on preterm infants was less clear.
population_specificity: Premature and healthy term infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of postpartum high-dose vitamin A supplementation and fortified oil consumption on plasma and milk retinol concentrations in lactating Moroccan women.
results_summary: The study found that serum retinol concentration was higher in the group receiving vitamin A fortified oil compared to the non-fortified oil group at 6 months postpartum.
population_specificity: Lactating Moroccan women aged 19-40 years within the first month of giving birth.
effective_dosage: Single high-dose vitamin A (200,000 IU) postpartum, followed by weekly vitamin A fortified oil or non-fortified oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors influencing catch-up growth in preterm infants after discharge, with a focus on feeding strategies involving milk.
results_summary: The study found that factors like gestational age, caregivers' education, daily milk volume, and breast milk supplementation influenced catch-up growth in preterm infants, with only 17.4% not meeting growth criteria at 12 months.
population_specificity: Preterm infants and their caregivers from five women's and children's hospitals.
study_duration: Follow-up until 12 months of actual age

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether whey protein supplementation (PrS) combined with resistance training (RT) improves muscle mass, strength, and functional outcomes in hospitalized geriatric patients compared to placebo.
results_summary: Both protein and placebo groups showed significant improvements in muscle mass, strength, and quality of life, but no additional benefit was observed from whey protein supplementation over placebo. The primary endpoint (30-s chair stand test) and secondary endpoints showed no statistically significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Geriatric patients (>70 years) hospitalized and followed for 12 weeks post-discharge.
effective_dosage: 27.5 g whey protein per day, divided into two servings.
study_duration: During hospitalization (variable length) and 12 weeks post-discharge.

study_goal: To determine the effect of feeding with formula compared with donor breast milk on growth and development in preterm or low birth weight (LBW) infants.
results_summary: Formula-fed infants showed higher in-hospital rates of weight gain, linear growth, and head growth but had an increased risk of necrotising enterocolitis. No significant effects were found on long-term growth, neurodevelopment, or all-cause mortality.
population_specificity: Preterm or low birth weight (LBW) infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with bovine milk fat globule membrane (MFGM) concentrates improves infant and child health, particularly in defense against infections.
results_summary: Three of five reviewed studies found a protective effect against infections in infants and young children. MFGM supplementation also showed moderate effects on the microbiome, metabolome, and lipidome.
population_specificity: Infants and young children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review protein and amino acid physiology in newborns, particularly very preterm infants, and evaluate current recommendations for protein supplementation in human milk.
results_summary: The study found that human milk alone does not meet the protein needs of very preterm infants, necessitating supplementation or fortification. Recent studies have explored varying parenteral amino acid intakes, leading to updated recommendations.
population_specificity: Very preterm infants (<32 weeks gestation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the prevalence and implications of vitamin D deficiency, particularly in breastfed infants, and discuss recommendations for supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that breast milk contains inadequate vitamin D, leading to higher risks of rickets in children and subclinical deficiency in adults, and recommended daily vitamin D supplementation for breastfed infants. It also highlighted broader systemic effects of vitamin D deficiency, including immune dysfunction and pregnancy complications.
population_specificity: Breastfed infants, children with rickets, and adults with osteomalacia or subclinical deficiency.
effective_dosage: 400 international units of vitamin D daily for breastfed infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal maternal thiamine dose required to increase infant thiamine diphosphate concentrations in breast milk and assess its impact on cognitive development.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it seeks to evaluate the dose-response relationship of thiamine supplementation in lactating women and its effect on infant thiamine levels and cognitive outcomes. Final results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: 320 lactating women from Kampong Thom, Cambodia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dilute or full-strength formula is preferable for preterm or low birth weight infants when expressed breast milk is unavailable, focusing on outcomes like necrotising enterocolitis, feeding intolerance, and weight gain.
results_summary: The study found that dilute formula may reduce feeding intolerance (e.g., fewer gastric residuals, vomiting, and abdominal distension) and help infants achieve adequate energy intake faster, but data on serious gastrointestinal issues like necrotising enterocolitis were not reported.
population_specificity: Preterm or low birth weight infants exclusively formula-fed (no breast milk supplementation).
effective_dosage: Dilute (double-volume, half-strength) vs. full-strength (20 kcal/oz or ~68-70 kcal/100 mL) formula.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of home-based ready-to-use therapeutic food (RUTF), including formulations with milk powder, on recovery, relapse, mortality, and weight gain in children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
results_summary: Standard RUTF (with milk powder) likely improves recovery and slightly increases weight gain compared to alternative dietary approaches, but its effects on relapse and mortality remain unclear. Alternative RUTF formulations showed little difference in efficacy except for reduced relapse with standard RUTF.
population_specificity: Children aged six months to five years with SAM, including HIV-infected and uninfected or untested children.
effective_dosage: Not specified (RUTF formulations varied, some meeting WHO nutritional composition standards).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of food fortification, including staple foods like milk, as a long-term solution for addressing vitamin D deficiency at a population level.
results_summary: The study suggests that food fortification, particularly with staple foods, is the most effective method for increasing vitamin D consumption and treating deficiency long-term, compared to short-term supplementation. It highlights the limitations of relying solely on sunlight exposure or dietary intake for adequate vitamin D levels.
population_specificity: General population with vitamin D deficiency (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of vitamin D supplementation via tablets versus vitamin D fortified milk in improving vitamin D status and metabolic syndrome (MetS) markers in adolescents.
results_summary: Vitamin D fortified milk (200 ml/day, 40IU/100 ml) showed a statistically significant increase in 25(OH)D levels but was less effective than tablets. The milk group had a 19.8% increase in vitamin D levels compared to 34.7% in the tablet group, with no significant reduction in MetS incidence.
population_specificity: Saudi adolescents (12-18 years old) attending schools in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.
effective_dosage: 200 ml/day of vitamin D fortified milk (40IU/100 ml).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose vitamin D supplementation increases the risk of milk allergy in infants.
results_summary: The study found that infants administered 30 μg vitamin D had a higher risk of milk allergy compared to those given 10 μg. No significant differences were observed for other allergic outcomes.
population_specificity: 975 infants from 2 weeks to 12 months of age.
effective_dosage: 10 μg (400 IU) or 30 μg (1200 IU) daily.
study_duration: From 2 weeks to 12 months of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of public health measures in reducing iodine deficiency among pregnant and lactating women in Australia.
results_summary: Three of seven studies showed iodine sufficiency (MUIC >150 μg/L or BMIC >100 μg/L), while four found mild-to-moderate deficiency (MUIC <150 μg/L). Antenatal iodine supplementation was most consistently linked to adequate iodine status.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating women in Australia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming steamed, dehydrated, and encapsulated placenta affects postpartum prolactin levels and neonatal weight gain compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in plasma prolactin levels or neonatal weight gain between the placenta and placebo groups, suggesting no measurable effect on lactation outcomes.
population_specificity: Postpartum women (N = 27)

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the role of probiotic treatments, including bifidobacteria, in addressing dysbiotic conditions of the gut microbiota and their potential therapeutic effects on enteric disorders and other human pathologies.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Milk's effects, only mentioning the potential of probiotic treatments for gut microbiota-related conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers were examining breast imaging challenges during pregnancy and lactation, including the presentation and diagnosis of pregnancy-associated breast cancer (PABC).
results_summary: The study highlights that breast imaging during pregnancy and lactation requires modifications to balance maternal and fetal well-being, with mammography being safe during pregnancy. PABC may present with symptoms like milk rejection, but the abstract does not focus on milk's effects.
population_specificity: Pregnant and lactating women, particularly those with clinical symptoms or diagnosed PABC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of biotin intake from milk and other foods on streptavidin/biotin-based immunoassays.
results_summary: Normal biotin intake from milk does not interfere with immunoassays, but excessive biotin consumption (100-300 mg daily) can disrupt test results for various biomarkers. No rapid detection method for biotin interference currently exists.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of patients with biotinidase deficiency, metabolic disorders, or emergency situations.
effective_dosage: Normal dietary intake (unspecified) vs. overconsumption (100-300 mg daily).
interactions: Biotin interference noted in immunoassays for thyroid markers, drugs, hormones, and other biomarkers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tolerance and safety of hydrolyzed liquid protein (LP) supplement added to fortified human milk (HM) for optimizing protein intake in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that hydrolyzed LP was well tolerated with no significant impact on feeding intolerance, NEC, or metabolic acidosis. Growth metrics (weight and head circumference) showed no statistically significant differences between groups.
population_specificity: Preterm infants receiving mothers' own milk (MOM) and/or donor milk (DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of vitamin D in fertility, pregnancy outcomes, and lactation, including its supplementation effects.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy improves vitamin D and calcium status, protecting skeletal health, but its effects on fertility, adverse pregnancy outcomes, and infant wheeze/asthma remain unclear. Observational data linked vitamin D deficiency to reduced fertility, adverse pregnancy outcomes, and low vitamin D content in breast milk.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and general population (fertility, lactation contexts).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review gaps in the literature regarding probiotic use in preterm infants, focusing on the impact of feeding type (mother's milk, donor milk, formula) on probiotic efficacy and clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the need for further research to clarify the relationship between probiotic supplementation and clinical outcomes based on feeding type, as well as the comparative efficacy of multi-strain vs. single-strain probiotics. Safety concerns, such as antibiotic resistance and long-term effects, were also identified as areas requiring investigation.
population_specificity: Very low-birth-weight infants (preterm infants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a standardized feeding protocol and hospital-based milk bank in preventing necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in extremely low birth weight infants.
results_summary: The study found that using preterm human milk (maternal or donor) with a standardized feeding protocol resulted in a low incidence of NEC (1%). Full feeds were achieved at a median of 27 days, and fortification was used selectively for inadequate weight gain.
population_specificity: Extremely low birth weight (ELBW) infants (mean gestational age 26.2 weeks) who survived to day 14 without congenital anomalies.
effective_dosage: Initial trophic feeds from days 7 to 14, followed by advancement of 15 mL/kg/day to reach a goal of 180 mL/kg/day.
study_duration: From birth until full feeds were achieved (median 27 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nutritional supplementation (fortified milk powder) combined with cognitive stimulation improves cognitive functioning in normally developing but at-risk children.
results_summary: The experimental group receiving fortified milk and cognitive stimulation showed significantly higher IQ increases and reduced attentional problems compared to the control group. The results suggest that combined nutritional and psychosocial interventions can enhance cognitive outcomes in healthy but at-risk children.
population_specificity: Normally developing children in Indonesia at risk for suboptimal cognitive development due to limited psychosocial stimulation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fortified vs. unfortified milk powder, exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (abstract does not state intervention length).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether earlier introduction of nutrient supplements improved nutritional outcomes in moderately preterm to late preterm low birth weight babies.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the nutrient supplements.
population_specificity: Low birth weight babies between 31 and 39 weeks' gestation admitted to a Special Care Nursery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify sensory preferences for supplemented food products (SFP), including fresh milk-based supplements, among cancer patients and evaluate the methodologies used in sensory preference assessment.
results_summary: The review found that cancer patients' liking for SFP differs from healthy participants, with a preference for fresh milk-based supplements over other types. However, patient heterogeneity and methodological variations complicated definitive conclusions about treatment effects on taste preferences.
population_specificity: Cancer patients (varying in tumor site and stage) compared with healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carbohydrate supplementation of human milk improves growth, body composition, and cardio-metabolic and neurodevelopmental outcomes in preterm infants without significant adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that preterm infants receiving carbohydrate-supplemented human milk had greater weight gain at 30 days compared to the unsupplemented group, but the evidence was of very low quality. No clear differences were observed in feeding intolerance or necrotising enterocolitis risk.
population_specificity: Preterm infants in hospital settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementing infant formula with bovine milk fat globule membranes (MFGM) could narrow immunological and cognitive development gaps between breast-fed and formula-fed infants.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in lipidome profiles (e.g., sphingomyelins, phosphatidylcholines) between infants fed MFGM-supplemented formula and standard formula, suggesting MFGM's role in cognitive and immunological benefits. These effects were detectable at 4 and 6 months but not at 12 months.
population_specificity: Formula-fed infants (160 participants) and a breast-fed reference group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of three nutritional supplements, including a milk-based fortified food, on dietary energy and nutrient intake in young children.
results_summary: Children receiving the milk-based fortified food showed smaller increases in dietary energy and protein intake compared to those receiving syrup, with no significant differences in micronutrient intake. The study suggests that micronutrient powders may be a better option for children meeting minimum energy and protein requirements.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-12 months in urban communities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preterm formula (PF) could provide feeding tolerance comparable to pasteurized donor human milk (PDHM) in very preterm infants when own mother's milk (OMM) was insufficient or unavailable.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the time to achieve full enteral feeding (FEF) between infants fed PF and those fed PDHM, suggesting PF is a valid alternative for early feeding in very preterm infants. Both groups achieved FEF in approximately 12 days.
population_specificity: Very preterm infants with gestational age ≤32 weeks who started enteral feeding within the first 7 days of life.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin K supplementation, alone or combined with other nutrients, on pregnant women and their newborns, focusing on outcomes like neonatal bleeding and maternal plasma VK1 levels.
results_summary: The study found that vitamin K supplementation significantly increased maternal plasma VK1 levels but showed no significant effect on neonatal bleeding. Some benefits were noted for maternal breast milk VK and serum VK levels in mothers and newborns, but many outcomes were unassessed or inadequately reported.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (varying gestational ages) and their newborns, primarily from high-income countries.
effective_dosage: Varying dosages and durations (not specified in abstract).
